categories.name: Investment/Trading Scam
categories.description: Investment or trading scams involve fraudulent schemes where scammers lure victims into fake investment opportunities, promising high returns with little or no risk. These scams often use social media ads, fake investment platforms, or Ponzi schemes. Victims may be asked to invest in stocks, forex, cryptocurrencies, or other financial products, but eventually, the scammers disappear with their money. They often impersonate legitimate financial advisors or companies to gain trust. Common tactics include pressure to invest quickly, fake testimonials, and manipulated trading dashboards showing fake profits.

categories.name: Online Job Fraud
categories.description: Online job fraud occurs when scammers deceive job seekers with fake employment opportunities. They often post fake job listings on websites, social media, or send unsolicited messages offering high-paying jobs with minimal effort. Victims may be asked to pay upfront fees for job applications, background checks, or training materials. Some fraudsters pose as legitimate companies, sending fake offer letters and requesting sensitive personal or banking details. Work-from-home scams, fake recruitment agencies, and advance fee scams are common tactics used in online job fraud.

categories.name: Tech Support Scam/Customer Care Scam
categories.description: Tech support or customer care scams involve fraudsters pretending to be technical support representatives from legitimate companies. They contact victims through phone calls, pop-up ads, fake websites, or emails, claiming that their computer or device has a virus, security issue, or software problem. The scammers then trick victims into granting remote access, installing malware, or paying for unnecessary services. These scams often involve threats of data loss or legal consequences to pressure the victim into compliance.

categories.name: Online Loan Fraud
categories.description: Online loan fraud occurs when scammers pose as legitimate financial institutions or lenders, offering easy and fast loan approvals with minimal paperwork. They often target victims through fake websites, social media ads, or unsolicited messages. The fraudsters ask for an upfront processing fee or demand sensitive personal and banking details, which are then misused. Victims either receive no loan after paying the fee or their personal data is used for identity theft and unauthorized transactions.

categories.name: Romance Scam/Honey Trapping
categories.description: Romance scams, also known as honey trapping, involve fraudsters who build fake romantic relationships with victims online to manipulate them emotionally and financially. They typically operate through dating apps, social media, or email, gaining trust over time before requesting money for emergencies, travel, or fake investments. Scammers may use stolen photos and fake identities, and once they receive money, they often disappear. In honey trapping, victims may be blackmailed using personal or intimate information.

categories.name: Impersonation of Government Officials
categories.description: This scam involves fraudsters impersonating government officials such as police officers, tax authorities, or intelligence agency personnel to threaten or deceive victims into providing money or personal information. They may claim that the victim is under investigation or owes fines and must make immediate payments to avoid legal action. Often, they use caller ID spoofing, fake documents, and aggressive tactics to pressure victims into compliance.

categories.name: Impersonation Fraud (Non-Government)
categories.explanation: A sophisticated form of deception where criminals pose as legitimate entities, individuals, or organizations (excluding government bodies) to gain trust and extract money or sensitive information. This includes impersonating bank officials, technical support, company executives, or service providers. The fraudsters often create elaborate scenarios using stolen corporate logos, fake websites, or spoofed email addresses. They may claim system issues, account problems, or urgent financial matters to pressure victims into immediate action. Common tactics include requesting remote access to devices, asking for OTPs, or demanding immediate payments to resolve fabricated issues. The fraud can occur through various channels including phone calls, emails, SMS, or social media platforms. Perpetrators often use social engineering techniques and may have gathered preliminary information about the victim to make their impersonation more convincing.

categories.name: SIM Swap Fraud
categories.explanation: A targeted attack where criminals illegally obtain a duplicate SIM card of the victim's mobile number by exploiting telecom provider processes or through insider collusion. This enables them to receive all SMS and calls meant for the victim, including crucial OTPs and banking alerts. The fraud typically involves gathering personal information through social engineering or data breaches, using this to convince telecom providers to issue a new SIM, and then using the activated SIM to bypass two-factor authentication on various accounts. Fraudsters often coordinate this attack with accessing banking or payment applications, leading to unauthorized transactions. The victim typically experiences sudden loss of mobile network, followed by unauthorized access to their accounts and financial losses. This fraud is particularly dangerous as it bypasses standard SMS-based security measures and can compromise multiple accounts simultaneously.

categories.name: Sextortion/Nude Video Call Extortion
categories.explanation: A form of blackmail where criminals manipulate victims into compromising situations through video calls or social media interactions, then demand money to prevent the release of recorded intimate content. The fraud typically begins with perpetrators creating fake profiles (often using attractive photos) to initiate contact on social media or dating platforms. They convince victims to engage in intimate video calls, secretly recording the interaction. The fraudsters then threaten to share these recordings with the victim's friends, family, or colleagues unless payment is made. They often use sophisticated editing software to create more compromising content even if the actual interaction was limited. The extortion can be continuous, with demands for additional payments. This crime exploits victims' fear of social embarrassment and can have severe psychological impacts. Perpetrators often operate in organized groups and may target multiple victims simultaneously.

categories.name: Courier/Parcel Delivery Scam
categories.explanation: A deceptive scheme where fraudsters pose as representatives of legitimate courier or postal services to defraud victims. These scams typically involve notifications about fake packages, customs clearance, or delivery issues requiring immediate payment or personal information. Criminals often use sophisticated phishing websites that mimic legitimate courier services, sending messages about supposed delivery attempts, customs duties, or package holds. They may claim additional charges for international shipping, customs clearance, or special handling fees. The scam might also involve malware-laden tracking links or fake delivery forms designed to steal personal and financial information. In some variations, fraudsters may actually deliver counterfeit items or empty packages to maintain the illusion of legitimacy. The scam exploits the growing popularity of online shopping and international shipping services.

categories.name: Phishing
categories.explanation: A cybercrime technique where attackers masquerade as legitimate institutions to trick victims into revealing sensitive information. Phishing attacks typically employ social engineering and technical subterfuge to steal personal identity data and financial account credentials. Attackers often create sophisticated replicas of legitimate websites, emails, or messages that appear to come from trusted sources like banks, social media platforms, or e-commerce sites. These communications usually contain urgent calls to action, such as account verification requirements, security alerts, or promotional offers. The fraud may involve multiple channels including email, SMS, voice calls (vishing), or social media messages. Advanced phishing attacks might use spear-phishing techniques targeting specific individuals with personalized content, or employ malware to capture keystrokes and other sensitive data. The success of these attacks often relies on creating a sense of urgency or fear to bypass the victim's normal security consciousness.

keywords_english.name: Aadhar Enabled Payment System (AEPS) Fraud/Biometric Cloning Fraud
keywords_english.explanation: A sophisticated fraud targeting India's biometric-based payment system where criminals exploit the Aadhaar-enabled payment infrastructure to conduct unauthorized transactions. This involves creating fake biometric data or illegally capturing legitimate biometric information (fingerprints, iris scans) of victims. Fraudsters may use techniques like creating artificial fingerprints, unauthorized storing of biometric data, or compromising point-of-sale devices. Common methods include setting up fake AEPS merchant points, collecting biometric data under false pretenses (like job applications or government schemes), or using compromised biometric readers. The fraud often targets less tech-savvy individuals, particularly in rural areas, and can lead to unauthorized withdrawals from linked bank accounts. Perpetrators might work in collusion with corrupt merchants or banking correspondents to execute these frauds. This type of fraud is particularly dangerous as it compromises both financial security and biometric data, which cannot be easily changed or reset like passwords.

keywords_english.name: Identity Theft
keywords_english.explanation: A comprehensive form of fraud where criminals steal and misuse personal information to impersonate victims for financial gain or other malicious purposes. This involves obtaining sensitive personal data including but not limited to name, address, date of birth, PAN card details, Aadhaar number, or banking information. Criminals may use this information to open new bank accounts, apply for loans or credit cards, file false tax returns, or access existing accounts. Methods of theft include phishing emails, data breaches, social engineering, dumpster diving for physical documents, or purchasing stolen data from dark web marketplaces. The impact can be long-lasting as criminals may use the stolen identity for extended periods, creating complex financial and legal problems for victims. Recovery often requires extensive documentation and coordination with multiple agencies to prove identity theft and restore the victim's credentials.

keywords_english.name: Courier/Parcel Delivery Scam
keywords_english.explanation: A sophisticated deception scheme where fraudsters impersonate legitimate courier services or postal operators to defraud victims. The scam typically involves fake notifications about package delivery, customs clearance issues, or delivery attempts requiring immediate payment or personal information verification. Criminals create convincing replica websites and apps of well-known courier companies, complete with tracking systems and customer service numbers. Common tactics include claiming additional charges for customs clearance, special handling fees, or international shipping costs. Fraudsters may send SMS or emails with malicious tracking links that steal personal data or banking credentials. Some variants involve delivering counterfeit items or empty packages to maintain legitimacy. The scam often exploits time pressure and urgency, claiming packages will be returned or destroyed without immediate action. More sophisticated versions may involve multiple touchpoints including fake delivery personnel, customer service calls, and official-looking documentation.

keywords_english.name: Phishing
keywords_english.explanation: A sophisticated cybercrime technique where attackers create deceptive digital communications that appear to come from legitimate sources to steal sensitive information. These attacks use social engineering and technical subterfuge to obtain personal and financial data. Criminals create exact replicas of legitimate websites, including banks, social media platforms, and e-commerce sites, often with only subtle differences in URLs. The scam typically involves urgent messages about account security, verification requirements, or attractive offers requiring immediate action. Phishing can occur through multiple channels including email (traditional phishing), SMS (smishing), voice calls (vishing), or social media messages. Advanced variants include spear-phishing (targeted attacks using personal information), whaling (targeting high-value individuals), and clone phishing (replicating legitimate messages with malicious links). Attackers often employ psychological triggers like urgency, fear, or greed, and may use current events or trending topics to make messages more convincing. The fraud might also involve malware deployment through attachments or downloads.

keywords_english.name: Online Shopping & E-Commerce Fraud
keywords_english.explanation: A complex category of fraud targeting digital retail platforms and e-commerce transactions, encompassing multiple deceptive practices in online shopping. Fraudsters create sophisticated fake online stores or exploit legitimate platforms to deceive buyers. Common methods include setting up counterfeit websites that mimic popular retailers, complete with stolen logos, product images, and fake reviews. Scammers may offer high-demand products at unusually low prices or claim exclusive deals on scarce items. The fraud can manifest as dropshipping scams delivering inferior products, non-delivery after payment, fake tracking information, or sale of counterfeit goods. Advanced schemes might involve compromised e-commerce accounts, manipulated seller ratings, or sophisticated payment system exploits. Perpetrators often create urgency through limited-time offers or exploit seasonal shopping events. The fraud may also include gathering financial information through fake checkout processes, pyramid schemes disguised as online businesses, or sophisticated refund frauds.

keywords_english.name: Real Estate/Rental Payment Fraud
keywords_english.explanation: A complex fraud scheme targeting property transactions and rental agreements, exploiting both traditional real estate processes and digital payment systems. Criminals create elaborate deceptions involving fake property listings, rental scams, fraudulent property sales, or compromised payment channels. Methods include listing non-existent properties, duplicating legitimate listings with altered contact information, or intercepting communications between parties involved in real estate transactions. Fraudsters may request advance payments for properties that don't exist, manipulate payment instructions in property purchases, or create sophisticated schemes with fake property documents and title deeds. The fraud often involves extensive documentation including forged property papers, fake identification, and manipulated payment systems. Advanced versions may include fake property viewings, impersonation of real estate professionals, or complex schemes involving multiple perpetrators coordinating different aspects of the fraud.

keywords_english.name: Other financial related fraud
keywords_english.explanation: A comprehensive category encompassing diverse financial frauds that combine elements of multiple fraud types or employ emerging technologies and platforms. This includes investment scams, cryptocurrency frauds, pension frauds, insurance scams, loan scams, and business email compromise (BEC) attacks. Fraudsters often create sophisticated investment platforms, fake financial products, or complex ponzi schemes. Methods may involve social engineering, manipulation of digital payment systems, or exploitation of new financial technologies. Common variants include cryptocurrency investment scams, pension fund fraud, insurance claim fraud, fake loan offers, and business email compromise leading to fraudulent transfers. The category also covers emerging frauds targeting digital wallets, UPI payments, or new financial products. Perpetrators frequently adapt their methods to exploit new technologies, regulations, and financial trends, making these frauds particularly challenging to detect and prevent. The impact can range from small losses to complete financial devastation, often involving complex schemes that are difficult to trace or recover from.
